bioghist.p: Richard Bauer (b. 1930) was a Presbyterian minister who was active in the area of national missions. Bauer was a 1955 graduate of McCormick Theological Seminary, and then served as pastor at Springdale Presbyterian Church, Springdale, Ohio, from 1955 to 1963. Beginning in 1963, he served as Field Administrator for National Missions in the Presbyterian Synod of Minnesota, Director of National Missions for Presybyterian Synod of Michigan, and Director for Texas Christian University. The 1982 General Assembly requested the General Assembly Mission Council to undertake a serious inquiry into the ability of the United Presbyterian Church "to deal...with social, political, and economic crises." Richard W. Bauer was appointed the Project Administrator. The final report was authored by Bauer and Donald L. Leonard and titled "An Historical Study of Past Denominational Responses to Social, Political and Economic Crises."

scopecontent.p: The collection relates to the research and writing of Bauer and Leonard's report on the Presbyterian response to crises in society. Included in this collection is a research plan, correspondence, mailing lists, handwritten notes, audiocassettes and notes for interviews, questionnaire responses, and drafts and Bauer's own copies of the final report and agendas for meetings. In addition there are photocopies from Presbyterian published materials, including General Assembly Mission Council minutes related to topics such as hunger, race, and civil rights; copies (some photocopies) of annual reports of the Hunger Program, 1976-1981; printed "Historical Overview" publications on various topics in the United Presbyterian Church in the United States of America, including racial-ethnic ministry policies, new church development policies, mission funding policies, Christian education, youth programs; and official memos and reports related to funding.
